- Hello, my name is Miriam McLemore
and I'm thrilled to be here with you today

to share the story of
transformation from Capital One.
Mark Mathewson from Capital One,
CIO of retail banking,
is gonna share their transformation story.
Like many organizations,
Capital One decided to transform to create

agility and innovation
for their organization.
But after the initial pilot,

scaling for the larger
organization did prove challenging.
And Mark is gonna share with us today

how they accomplished such
a broad transformation.

Mark, welcome. Could you please
further introduce yourself?

- Thanks, Miriam. Happy
to be here with you today.
As Miriam said, my name is Mark Mathewson.

I am the divisional
CIO for our retail bank

which entails responsibility
for all of our

software engineering and
operations and support
of our direct bank, our retail outlets
and branches and cafes nationally,

as well as all of the tools
that support the associates
who support that business.
- Mark, can you tell me a little bit more
about the DNA at Capital One

and the tech transformation
that you went through?
- I can.

Capital One has a really
interesting story.

We were founded on an
insight in the credit market
to try to solve for customer needs

that weren't being met by
other credit providers.
And we did that using data.
We did that with a very kind of innovative
sort of approach to banking.
And that's a thread that continues
through the company today and pretty much

everything that we do and
all of our businesses.

And so I would say our DNA
is really entrepreneurial,

which was really helpful
as we went through
our tech transformation.

And we started thinking about
this tech transformation
nine years ago.

I mean, it was a really broad
goal that the company had

to change how we operate
from the inside and out.

And really, the premise
behind how we wanted to change

was to become a technology
company that does banking,

rather than a bank that
leverages technology.
And while I think it's easy to say that,
it's really, really hard to do.
I mean, it requires that you transform
not only your infrastructure,
or you transform your talent model.

You have to transform the
way that people work together
to deliver a variety of outcomes.
And so we really started soup to nuts
with an intentional view
on how to transform ourselves

so that we could better
compete with where we believe
banking is going in the future.
- Yeah, Mark, and I love that comment
about being intentional.

Can you take us on the
journey from the initial pilot

to really broadening the
capability for the organization?

- Yeah, it was back in,
I believe it was 2014,

when we really first started
experimenting with the cloud.

And we started experimenting
internally with the cloud.

We had a fledgling capability
that we called our C cloud
which was a private cloud offering.
At the same time, we also had engineers
that were experimenting with AWS
starting to just figure out
how they could set up environments
and push small workloads,

develop some really
non-critical applications
out in the public cloud.

And at some point, we
got to a fork in the road

where we had to make a decision
on do we continue to invest
in building this private cloud capability
or do we take what's being developed

at a much more rapid pace
in the public cloud arena

and really jump all in on
leveraging the public cloud

so that we could have our
engineers really focus on

what our core competency is
and what we're here to do,

which is to build digital
customer experiences for banking.

And that answer when we
finally made the call
became a guiding principle for really
a lot of the rest of the transformation,
which was go all in on public cloud,
figure out how to work backwards
from what's gonna take to be successful
in going all in on public cloud

and changing how we think about
provisioning infrastructure

and changing how we think
about talent and skillsets
and changing all the practices that we use
as we work together as a company
to center around being a public cloud

versus a private cloud and
internally hosted organization.

- Mark, I love that focus on
what Capital One's mission is
and not spending time on cloud development

when you could leverage
partners as you did with AWS.

Can you share a couple of
examples of those that work

that Capital One to really
become a digital bank?
- Yeah, there's a lot of good examples,
and maybe what I'll do is take you through
a little bit of the journey.

We started really thinking
about how we worked

and we decided to pivot our
way of working into Agile.
I think we all remember the days
where everything was Waterfall

and they were these big
long provision projects
that took years.
And we decided that we needed to get

a much more agile and
rapid way of working.
And so we started thinking about
how do we change our team structure

and how we interact with
each other to be more agile.

And that took the form
of the Agile methodology,

but just a lot more
rapidly moving practices
to make sure that we could go fast.
And then we started thinking a bit more

about how we build things,
and we made a declaration

that we wanted to go all
in on developing APIs.

We're gonna interact, our
software was gonna be,
we're gonna interact with other components
internally based on APIs,
and we were going to make our services

that are externally
available through APIs.
And then we started talking about
leveraging open-source software,

like how are we gonna
leverage open-source software

rather than proprietary
third party products
to build our software?
So these were all just key pieces
that we started thinking about
how do we start to really operate
more like a technology company.
And as we started doing those things,
we said, "Well, now this is great,
but how do we leverage the cloud
as the infrastructure component of that

that enables all of those
pieces to come together

in terms of how we get
products out to market
in a very rapid way.

We've got the scalable
infrastructure available.
We have interoperable APIs.
We've got open-source software
that helps to attract talent and is also

easy to find developers who
understand how to incorporate
those things into solutions.
And you put that all together,

and that really became
a pretty powerful recipe

for how we get products to
market a lot more quickly.
And as evidence points of that,
we have seen over time that now,

it used to take us months to
provision new infrastructure

for a new project, and
really get engineers going
and shipping features.

Now we can provision that
infrastructure really in minutes
and get that out to developers hands

in ways that they can actually
start experimenting quickly.

We're also seeing in
production that we're able
to more rapidly release new features
out to the marketplace.

It used to be months where we
would have release schedules,
quarterly or monthly release schedules.

Now in many cases for a
lot of our applications

we're seeing release schedules
that are more in days

and sometimes in hours, which
has really been game changing
and really powerful for us.

- And for me, that is
game changing within IT,

not having those wait
times and really being able
to respond to your business requirements.
Has the business felt it as well?
Do they see the power of cloud?
- Yeah, it's a great question,
and I will say it's been a journey,
but now, they really do,
and I think for a couple of reasons.

During this transformation,
not only did we just say,

"Hey, let's turn on the cloud
for a bunch of engineers."

We spent a lot of time
laying the foundation

across the business, really,
and the messaging came

from the top on why do
we wanna use the cloud.
What are the benefits of the cloud?
And we really empowered our engineers

to help tell that story to
their business partners,
and we as leaders spent a lot of time
talking to our business partners
around why prioritize this work
of picking up existing workloads
and migrating them into the cloud?
And we spent a lot of time talking about

one of the things I've already
mentioned, which is speed.
When we make this investment,
look how quickly we're gonna be able

to get new features out
and new capabilities out
versus what we were able to do before.
We talked a lot about talent.

These are the tools and
capabilities that the market

of software engineering
talent out there demand.
And if we wanna stay ahead of the game

and be able to attract
the best and brightest

to deliver the types of
capabilities that we need
to build digitally,

the only way to do that is to
offer tools and technologies
that those engineers really value.

And so we spend a lot of
time laying the ground work
and helping our business leaders
across the organization understand that.

It took some time, it
took some consistency,
but now we really do have strong buy in.
And we actually have seen evidence
throughout different scenarios

that have further reinforced
for our businesses

why the value of the cloud was
so important on our journey.

- So Mark, data is obviously
a very powerful asset

at Capital One and any
kind of company today,
but particularly I would think in banking.

Can you tell us a little
bit about the power

that this technology
transformation has unlocked
for the use of data for your organization?
- Absolutely.
And it really ties back to something

I mentioned earlier in the
founding of the company.
We were founded on a thing we like to call

information-based strategy,
which is all about

how you unlock the power
of data to find insights

that others may not
easily be able to find.

And that really takes
building great infrastructure
to be able to use the data that you have
to quickly run analytics,
to quickly find those insights,
and to quickly put those back into play

in terms of business
decisions and strategies.

And the tech transformation
for us has really changed

how we're able to build
that infrastructure.

By making the decision
to go all in on cloud,

we've been able to unlock
a lot of silos of data
that have traditionally been

in various different
pockets of the organization
and put them all in one place.
So we now have a lake based in the cloud
that offers analytics on any type of data

that we capture or produce
throughout the organization.
And it's a thing that we just absolutely

wouldn't have been able
to do with the speed
that we're able to do it now in the cloud.

It also allows us to rethink
about how we govern that data.

I mean, anybody who's been
in this industry a long time

just knows that data
management and data governance
is one of the key challenges.

Well, now that you've gotta
rearchitect all that data

in the cloud, you have
the opportunity to rethink

how do you capture all
the data quality measures
that you need at source?
How do you put the right controls in place

so that when data is
published, it's clean,
we know what that data is, it's labeled,
and we know the quality of that data

before it gets consumed
by analytical processes

or models that we build
with it downstream.

And so it really, the
transformation has given us

an opportunity to really
rethink all of that
from top to bottom,
and the infrastructure that we now have

and the tools that we
now have at our disposal
have allowed us to do that at scale.

So that not only do we have
that data all in one place,

but we've got the type
of compute power to run
almost any kind of workload on that data
to feed into models, fraud models
to feed into customer decisioning models,
to feed into recommendation engines,
a variety of different things.

So it really has been
a dramatic improvement

to our capabilities to
produce better analytics.
- Yeah, I love that.
And you spoke earlier about the education
that you did for the business on cloud
and the capabilities that would bring

and imagine the example
of data is powerful

in really connecting the
dots for the business
and the technology.
And often in customers that I speak to

there's some tension
between the product team
and the tech team.

Can you share a little
bit about how you've used
both the education
and the power of those data examples
to break down some of those walls?
And I think you said create

kind of a shared ownership
model, is that right?
- Yeah, that is correct.
It's an ongoing discussion for us,

and one that I think we're
getting a lot better at,

which is instead of having
product and business people

who just think about
what is the next feature
that I need to get out to a customer
and tech people who think about
how do I solve vulnerabilities
or how do I produce data streams
off of existing infrastructure,

and things that really feel
a lot more behind the scenes
to business people traditionally.

We've really gotten our
product and engineering teams

to work together and think
about joint ownership.
If we think about a data product,

how do we not only make
sure that that data product

has high quality data,
is easily consumable,

but also that it sits on
resilient infrastructure
that it is secure,

or data is tokenized or
encrypted were needed.
The only way when you work together
between tech and product to make sure

that both understand all
of those considerations,
you end up with not just a great product

that provides something
useful to customers,

but one that provides
something useful to customers
that's also secure, that's also reliable

that has market leading uptime,
and those kind of things.
And I think you only get that
by creating that shared ownership.
If you've got great features
that fall over in the middle of the night,
that doesn't help anybody.

But now that you've got
our business partners

and product partners
understanding the value

of the reliability that we
can now build into products,
they're really just as interested
in pushing those things forward

as we on the engineering
and technology side are.
- Yeah, I think that's very powerful.
So what is next in Capital One's journey?
Are you done or does the journey continue?
- It is never done. It is never done.
I think what's next for us in the journey

is just continuing down the
path of building cloud native,
highly resilient and reliable services.

When you go to the
cloud, we're able to take
a portion of our applications
and modernize them along the way.
Obviously, some applications,

as we went all in on the
cloud we had to pick 'em up.

We had to lift them
and shift them in place
and put them into the cloud.
And so now we continue to just think about

how do we modernize all of
the remaining applications
that weren't modernized along the way,
leveraging cloud native services

that are continuously
developed and improved
by providers like AWS,

and rebuilding those clouds
in those applications

in a much more modernized
way is thing one.

The second thing that is
next for us on the journey

is really a continued
move towards serverless.
We really believe that,
our engineers want to build features.
They want to build data products,
they want to build and deploy models,
and they wanna ship rapidly,
and they don't wanna spend
their time managing infrastructure.
There's a lot of pain that comes
with managing container images on servers.
There's lots of pain that comes
with keeping up with vulnerabilities,

lots of pain associated with
configuration management
across a variety of different platforms.

And so the push towards
serverless we really believe in,

and really believe that as
we continue our journey,

getting to the place where
engineers can write code

and deploy that code,
and not have to worry
about any of the underlying infrastructure
that manages or runs that code,

or any of the vulnerabilities
or concerns behind that,
we're gonna have a much more

much more powerful
experience for our engineers

and a lot more
productivity, quite frankly,

rather than spending time
on a bunch of the mundane
and run the engine type tasks
that we've had to in the past.

- Yeah, and I do think
there's such great power
in serverless and making that move.
Is there any advice that you would have

for others that are
embarking on that journey?
- Yeah.
I think probably the biggest thing
has to do with governance.
It's a different context for thinking
about how to run your workloads.
And for many of us who have been running
server-based workloads for years,
we've gotten really good at how to control

those configurations, how to
manage the configurations,

how to keep up with
vulnerabilities over time,

and how to otherwise govern
a server-based concept.

Serverless is a different
construct, but still has,
especially for a regulated industry,

implications that you
really need to think about

so that you can understand
how your applications
are remaining in compliance

sitting on top of a
serverless infrastructure.

Where are the risks within
a serverless infrastructure
and how do you build controls in the cloud

in a way that you can control
for those risks without fear?

Because the last thing
that you want is to get

into a different compute context
that you don't understand
and later find the risks and gaps

that open you up to data
protection exposures

or operational risk failures
inside of the environment.

So I think the biggest thing
is just to really make sure
that you understand what is different
about that compute construct,
what is different about the risks,

and what type of controls
that you need to automate
and make sure that are in place
to use it safely and effectively.

that Capital One has
been on and continues on.

A bit tongue and cheek
to say are you done,
I believe like you do, you're never done,

but getting to those next
level of capabilities
like serverless is very powerful.

So thank you so much for
your time and your insights.
- Absolutely.
Thank you, Miriam. It's been a pleasure.
